bibl.title: The Curious Case of Kom Aushim Inv. no. 45. The Rediscovery of a Fragment from a Lost Inscription?
bibl.note: KA 45 is a basalt fragment (with three lines of Greek text) seized by Egyptian police off the antiquities market in Fayum City in 1999. It seems very probable that KA 45 once belonged to I. Fayoum I, 17 (= S.B. I, 624), seen by Seymour de Ricci on the antiquities market in Medinet el-Fayum in 1905 and again in 1908. ""Inscription honorifique émanant d'une association de machairophores"", late Ptolemaic period.
bibl.seg: Lincoln H. Blumell & Mostafa F. Hemieda, The Curious Case of Kom Aushim Inv. no. 45. The Rediscovery of a Fragment from a Lost Inscription?

KA 45 is a basalt fragment (with three lines of Greek text) seized by Egyptian police off the antiquities market in Fayum City in 1999. It seems very probable that KA 45 once belonged to I. Fayoum I, 17 (= S.B. I, 624), seen by Seymour de Ricci on the antiquities market in Medinet el-Fayum in 1905 and again in 1908. ""Inscription honorifique émanant d'une association de machairophores"", late Ptolemaic period.
